chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: SISC is a lightweight, platform independent interpreter of the algorithmic language Scheme. The goal of the SISC interpreter is to create a runtime for Scheme that is a correct and complete implementation of the R5RS Scheme standard, and all future standards, as well as provide a useful set of extensions for real-world programming.

itemizedlist.listitem: Full R5RS compliance with no exceptions
Efficient number tower, with arbitrary precision integers, rationals, and floating point and complex numbers.
Lightweight Scheme engine, requiring less than 200k of code.
Extensibility through runtime-loadable modules, which may add new functions and first-class types.

section.title: Architecture
section.para: SISC's architecture is broken up into four conceptual components: the Runtime, Compiler, Engine, and Modules.

The Runtime is a purely conceptual component, which simply consists of a platform independent Runtime on which SISC is built. At the time of this writing, only a single Runtime, the Java Virtual Machine, is supported.

The Compiler contains of the parser and lexer, an analyzer, and optionally a compiler. The parser and lexer turn unicode text representing Scheme code and Data into Scheme s-expressions. Then, the analyzer turns the s-expressions into an intermediate form called SISC Expressions. If present, a compiler may then take the SISC Expressions and generate runtime bytecode. Currently no compiler exists.

The Engine drives the evaluation of Scheme programs, by providing a register set, a set of environments, and an execution model (implemented as an Object Oriented hierarchy of Expressions). It is the design of an engine that operates on the intermediate Expressions that provides efficient interpretation of Scheme code with support for first-class continuations.

Finally, Modules extend the Engine to implement the Scheme builtin functions described in the Scheme standard that cannot be written in terms of other Scheme code, or code that benefits by running natively on the Runtime.
